Unfortunatelly 2.7.0 is already in use on Wallaby, you released it few days ago.

We are stuck with bugfix versions on victoria. It should be 2.6.2.

https://opendev.org/openstack/releases/blame/branch/master/deliverables/wallaby/oslo.cache.yaml#L10

Here I'd rather bump 2.7.0, because of

* 886928c (HEAD -> stable/victoria, tag: 2.6.2, origin/stable/victoria) Add dogpile.cache.pymemcache backend

But as far as I see, it is used already in wallaby. I'm curious why isn't the major version bumped with the new branch? In my understanding Wallaby should be 3.0.0.

> Here I'd rather bump 2.7.0, because of
> 
> * 886928c (HEAD -> stable/victoria, tag: 2.6.2, origin/stable/victoria) Add dogpile.cache.pymemcache backend
> 
> But as far as I see, it is used already in wallaby. I'm curious why isn't the major version bumped with the new branch? In my understanding Wallaby should be 3.0.0.

A cycle should start at least with a minor version, on oslo we don't start our series with major version. Oslo are common libraries so we try to stick to semver to reflect the reality of the changes for our users, proposing a major version will reflect that we introduced breaking changes and that's not true.

-1: I do not think we want to enforce multipath, because that will cause glance operations to fail if *any* of the paths are down. I believe nova might want to enforce multipath for HA purposes, but for glance and cinder itself, we want the operation to succeed as long as any path is available.

In other words, I think you should just delete L531.

I shouldn't have written "if *any* paths are down," although my point still stands. Typically, multipath deployments specify 2 paths, and so if either of them go down you no longer have multiple paths. That's what I meant by "if *any* paths are down." I should have said "when *either* (of two) paths are down."

ansible/roles/common/templates/conf/filt.message: Does this allow the logs to be parsed? It's in quite a different format isn't it?

Yes, well, kind of. These uWSGI logs now get picked up in `templates/conf/input/04-openstack-wsgi.conf.j2` like the other WSGI logs. In there we just ingest the whole message, see the line `format /^(?<Payload>.*)$/`. So we don't extract any fields, but we don't need to worry about the exact log format either. I've checked it works by searching for 'announcing my loyalty to the Emperor' (a uWSGI thing) and it shows up in Kibana. I don't think we should go any further with parsing these. On the other hand, all the Barbican API service logs are now parsed correctly like other OpenStack service logs.

openstack/utils.py.message:
I don't understand what you are saying here.

The test here -- which takes place at definition/import time - is to check to see whether we have a version of python that includes the new usedforsecurity flag.  It is not a check for FIPS.

If the test in line 237 succeeds, then md5(string, usedforsecurity) will be defined in a way that calls hashlib.md5 using the new flag.

If not, then we define md5(string, usedforsecurity) to call hashlib.md5 without the new flag.

Ah, I understand.  Yes, that is a good simplification.

The check for 3.9 won't work though, because there are some downstream python versions that already support this attribute. (Centos/RHEL in particular) and we want to support them.

I'll add a version with your simplification.
Maybe handle the exception and provide a helpful message with "Either use Python 3.9 or disable FIPS"?

OK, so in this case, catching the exception that would be thrown on line 252 - logging the exception and presumably rethrowing it.  I'm not sure there is much benefit to that and it would be problematic.  On a FIPS enabled system, we end up with a ValueError - which we'd need to disentagle from other ValueErrors.  The error cauase is also pretty clear.

ValueError: [digital envelope routines: EVP_DigestInit_ex] disabled for FIPS

See above, this is simply supposed to be a check as to whether the python being used supports md5.  The exception that is thrown here - at definition time - is in response to the call at line 237.  This is not a test of whether FIPS is enabled.
The exception I'm talking about is thrown in FIPS mode on Python < 3.9 on any access to this call.
Seens redundant to me, and I'd prefer the code to be explicit about usedforsecurity.
We can drop this one.  I needed to add it to swift to handle some collection code there, but its not needed here.

A TODO to remove this when our minimum Python version is bumped to 3.9 (which is the first upstream version to support this keyword [1]) would help long-term code maintenance efforts

[1] https://docs.python.org/3.9/library/hashlib.html?highlight=usedforsecurity

neutron_lib/api/definitions/address_grou.message: Don't you need the required_by_policy and enforce_policy to be set in this case?

Digging a little bit more, here's an experiment I ran: http://paste.openstack.org/show/802589/

As you can see, enforce_policy doesn't need to be set. That is because Neutron's policy ignores enforce_policy for get operations: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/73e1175602cca12138b4e406f6f50efc45238808/neutron/policy.py#L110.

Oslo policy engine checks anyway the entire rule and hits https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/772460/7/neutron/conf/policies/address_group.py#31, which is what we need for RBAC

zuul/zk/zuul.py.message: I'm not a huge fan of adding such code for IDE type checking support. Perhaps this is a symptom of using a Mixin, would it be more appropriate to use functions instead and replace self by a zuul.zk.ZooKeeper instance?

Yes, thats because of the mixin approach. I was trying the function approach too. But did not like the result either. I am open to suggestions. The goal here was to break up the ZooKeeper God-Class. This will become even a larger one due to the focus on Zookeeper as a central component

IIUC PS28, the current design is:


               BaseClient
                 /    \
                /      \
             Nodepool  Zuul
                \       /
                 \     /
                   Zk


I find it difficult to follow the state where all the methods and internal state are shared amongs these object. As an improvement, I suggest this design:

    Zk:
      client = BaseClient()
      nodepool = Nodepool(client)
      zuul = Zuul(client)

Where the client provides a higher level interface of the kazooclient with its internal state hidden from Nodepool and Zuul. The downside is that call site needs to be changed from `zk.getHoldRequest` to `zk.nodepool.getHoldRequest`.
I like your suggesstion also more: I changed that.

I thought we were having issues with multiple conductors on the same host (as they have the same hostname), but after diving with code it seems current lock implementation works.
Currently we don't support tuning conductor process number, I wonder if we have other considerations for not doing so?

In theory it should be fine for the pxe and image cache management, a request will only be delivered to one conductor process (with the same topic) in the case of rabbitmq, so for a time window there is only one process servicing the node. I am just going ahead to do some test on this, as one concern is one conductor service can't fully utilize the resources of the host. We're using agent and turned off image conversion, so the overload for a conductor should be light.

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

doc/source/admin/tuning.rst.message:
So, in theory it _should_ be fine. I've gone deep in to the code before, and this is actually why I wanted to be able to plug in a real DLM so we could be a lot safer about running concurrent processes. The thing that may go sideways with concurrent processes is tftpboot/httpboot folder management in terms of putting specific files in place and cleaning those up. Then again, if someone is needing that sort of scale, they may not necessarily need, or may not even worry about these sorts of things.

The other conundrum is who manages the launch. Operators that _DO_ this have written scripts to handle the launch and orchestration of processes launches. [u]wsgi will handle this for us in the process launch. *shrugs*

specs/wallaby/backlog/deferred-service-r.message:
I think we should also help the operator by:

 a) providing actions to actually affect the restart
 b) providing a status message that indicates a restart is pending

(Not sure how easy (b) would be to implement?)
I've updated the spec to include 'a'. The status message will show that restarts are deferred and I think it is realistic to extend that to show which individual services have a pending restart,

Surely this should be config, not actions?  It's something IMO that you want to enable or disable or on a application-wide basis, not a per-unit one.  Also, if you do it as an action, you need some way to provide visibility on whether restarts are currently enabled or disabled?  (Which you get for free if it's config)
I've updated the spec to use config rather than actions.

I can see some operators wanting to just leave restarts disabled. Rather than having an immediate-restart flag to the action, I think an explicit restart-services action allows for more flexibility in use cases.

As such, I think we may want to rename the {enable,disable}-restarts to {enable,disable}-auto-restarts and add a specific restart-service action.

I think there are a few cases/user stories I can think of here:

John will be upgrade the charms in his environment and wants to specifically control when service restarts will happen on each unit. John first disables automatic service restarts, upgrades the charm, restarts services one unit at a time, then resumes automatic service restarts.

Sally needs to be able to control when service downtime will occur. She disables automatic service restarts for the charms and leaves them disabled. As part of planned maintenance, she systematically runs through units and restarts services.

Luna's service has been restarted periodically due to a bug in the charm. While the bug is being resolved and fixed, Luna disables auto restarts on the services to prevent the charm from restarting. When the charm fix is delivered and installed, Luna resumes the auto restarts of the services to let the charm continue to manage things.

Thank you for the use-cases. I have updated the spec and included the switch from action to config option as well as adopting the `enable-auto-restarts` name. I believe that the new spec will cover all three of these use-cases.
If you mask the services in systemd, what happens on reboot of the system?
a masked service cannot be started either, so the service would remain stopped after a reboot. This may more easily be implemented with a systemd unit override (see systemctl edit).

Masking does not prevent the service from being stopped so my initial approach will not work. I have looked into the suggestion of using systemd overrides but this does not feel right. Ideally systemd should reject the stop or restart command rather than using an override to fool systemd into thinking the service has been stopped when it has not. 

As a result I have updated the spec to say that the charm will police itself and will not issue the stop or restart commands. As I mention in the update this is not ideal.

two things:
1. the _() should only encompass the literal string that will be translated.
2. use named interpolation when you have more than one variable (in case the translators need to change the order in a translated string)

So this would be:

  msg = _("volume %(volname)s creation exception: %(txt)s") %
        {'volname': volume_name, 'txt': str(e)}

Not really needed here because it's pretty obvious that THICK means thick provisioning, but the downside is that the generated file will look like this:

  # Thin or thick volume, Default thick. (string value)
  # Possible values:
  # THICK - <No description provided>
  # THIN - <No description provided>

which gives the reader the impression that you forgot to do something.  (Most of the cinder options look like the above because they were defined before oslo.config had this capability, and no one has gone back to add the descriptions.)

In any case, using the 'choices' is a good idea because the config tooling will prevent an operator from using an invalid string (or a string with a typo in it).  So up to you whether you want to enhance the documentation.

ignore_errors can hide errors that we don't intend/shouldn't ignore. The playbook then continues and may fail at a spot downstream that is harder for you to debug. It's not a good practice to use this directive in order to disregard the result of a task. ironic/common/policy.py.message: They exist only on the node objects, but I guess we need to cross-reference. I guess the question ends up being is there a simple way to effecitvely join the logic and check two values.

Ah, I think seeing this clarifies some lingering questions I had about how this rbac change would work. Essentially: node owner and node lessee no longer trickle down to the policy as a level of permission; instead, the role does. More concretely, if we previously had:

`"baremetal:node:update": "rule:is_admin or rule:is_node_owner"`

We'd now have (this may not be the correct syntax):

`"baremetal:node:update": "rule:PROJECT_ADMIN"`

Both an owner and a lessee with an `admin` role would match this new rule, so we would have to ensure that owners had the `admin` role while a lessee would be limited to a `member` role.

Is that correct? If so, would we be able to handle the case where an owner of one node wants to become the lessee of another node?

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

ironic/common/policy.py.message:
Going in reverse. I don't think there would be an issue of owner becoming the lessee of another node. They are two separate objects and would be two different evaluations.

As for what we would functionally have, I *think* so, but all negotiable. We could attempt to endevour to keep them separate. That being said I don't see another way to implement any native project support with the primarily system scoped model.

I think that's what doesn't make sense to me about defining PROJECT_ADMIN as:

PROJECT_ADMIN = ('(role:admin and project_id:%(owner)s or '
                 '(role:admin and project_id:%(lessee)')

That means if a user has the admin role in project A and leases another node, then they'd have PROJECT_ADMIN access to the leased node, correct? If so, I don't know if that's what we want.

I still have some pretty big concerns regarding this. As I see it, if I own a node and want to lease it to user A, then I don't actually know what level of access I'm granting that user, since (if I understand this correctly), it depends entirely on user A's role within their own project. I don't think we ever want a lessee to have project admin access.
My take is that being project-admin applies only to this node, and being a lessee of a node means its yours to do any operation for the duration of the lease.

Ah, I think that's my concern - when lessees were created, it was so that they would explicitly have less permissions on a node than an owner. For example, a lessee should never be able to arbitrarily update any attribute on a node; otherwise, they could just change the owner to themselves.

I think it'd be a mistake to potentially allow PROJECT_ADMIN access to a lessee.

If you think about this from the perspective of some automated code that is watching, it can be difficult to use this effectively. Basically, you need a client-side state machine *and* sufficiently-granular polling to catch each state. You need to see this /messages go through this sequence in order to deduce that the operation has completed:

 404 -> 200 -> 404

If you miss the 200, you may poll forever and not notice that you missed that it finished. If you miss the first 404, you might deduce that something else is running, that your task is queued, and will be processed afterwards. If you miss the second 404, you might not notice that your operation completed and someone else started another one, which will cause you to keep polling until that one has completed.

Point being, I think it would be better if we always return 200, and leave the "nothing is running" determination to the client by examining the results.

Can we add request-id in here? Without the request-id, the client has to look at the content here and decide "is this my request?" and "if it's not, is it good enough to satisfy what I wanted even if my request was dropped?"

In some cases it may be better to to the latter, but it's definitely more difficult and harder to do properly. In any situation where we need to report whether something worked or not, we need to know whether what we asked for succeeded or not.

As an example, imagine two nova computes that both ask for automatic copying of images to their respective stores. One compute node has a typo in its config which causes it to always ask for copying the image to the wrong place. However, since the end-user always boots lots of instances at the same time, there's usually an opportunity for the correctly-configured nova-compute to end up copying the image to the right place by luck. Without knowing that what it's asking for is not working, nova-compute can't log that its requests are failing. The operator occasionally gets reports from the user about things failing to boot (when they boot one instance and it lands on the broken node), but "most of the time" the problem seems to work itself out.

By making this a list, we can show all tasks from the past 24 hours or something, including completed ones. Thus, if I kick something off and then am unable to poll for a few minutes, I can still go back and determine that it was completed.

I sudden suggestion. Let's revert the switch to ddt. We've started reinventing Python's assert machinery in yaml, at this point it's saner to copy-paste many small Python methods that call the same function.

This was an expedient workaround to avoid the confusion of asserting 503 for unmocked API internals, vs mocking literally everything to return a legitimate 2xx.

The intent was that the positive and negative access-denied tests would be adjacent in the yaml file, and have test names which make it obvious that these specific tests are for allowed/denied checking.
